subject: QS Frequency Chart posted to Files Section
msgSnippet: There has been much tossed around lately about the frequency of QS letters (and how this affects new keyboard layouts.) Here is my humble contribution to the
messageBody:
There has been much tossed around lately about the frequency of QS
letters (and how this affects new keyboard layouts.) Here is my humble
contribution to the question,

For a convenient source, I used two of the largest texts in the files
section of the Shavian Group: a Sherlock Holmes story (70KB) and a chapter
of "The Uses of English" (58KB) The total character count was about 67,000,
20% of which were spaces. Of course, all transcriptions are affected by
the ear of the translator (and I think in both cases it was possibly
our reknown member Hugh) but we have to start somewhere, and I think the
results would much the same with different sources, at least for the first dozen
letters.

Here are the adjustments made to the originals:
1) Shavian "array" and "urge" were combined into QS "earth"
2) Shavian "ado" and "up" were combined into QS "ado" (one form only).
3) All ligatures were broken down into their components and assigned
to their root sounds.
4) Because of the source, of course, no ligatures or letter variants
were counted. (I think this to be an asset, We should be counting SOUNDS
not SHAPES!)

Because Yahoo, in their infinite wisdom, will not let me attach the
chart, I have posted it to the Read files section/resources. Enjoy! Feedback
appreciated.

There has been much tossed around lately about the frequency of QS
letters (and how this affects new keyboard layouts.) Here is my humble
contribution to the question,

For a convenient source, I used two of the largest texts in the files
section of the Shavian Group: a Sherlock Holmes story (70KB) and a chapter 
of "The Uses of English" (58KB) The total character count was about 67,000,

the ear of the translator (and I think in both cases it was possibly

results would much the same with different sources, at least for the first dozen
letters.

Here are the adjustments made to the originals:
1) Shavian "array" and "urge" were combined into QS "earth"
2) Shavian "ado" and "up" were combined into QS "ado" (one form only).
3) All ligatures were broken down into their components and assigned
to their root sounds.
4) Because of the source, of course, no ligatures or letter variants
were counted. (I think this to be an asset, We should be counting SOUNDS
not SHAPES!)

Because Yahoo, in their infinite wisdom, will not let me attach the
chart, I have posted it to the Read files section/resources. Enjoy! Feedback
appreciated.
